content.title: Anti-GBM Disease (Goodpasture Syndrome)
content.summary: Anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) disease is a rare autoimmune disorder caused by circulating antibodies against the alpha-3 chain of type IV collagen in glomerular and alveolar basement membranes. It presents as rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) with or without pulmonary hemorrhage (Goodpasture syndrome), requiring urgent plasmapheresis and immunosuppression.
key_points: Pathognomonic: Linear IgG staining along GBM on immunofluorescence
Target antigen: Alpha-3 chain of type IV collagen (Goodpasture antigen)
Pulmonary-renal syndrome (Goodpasture syndrome) in 60-80% of cases
Smoking increases risk of pulmonary hemorrhage in anti-GBM disease
Prognosis depends on initial creatinine; dialysis-dependent at presentation = poor renal outcome
content.statement: Anti-GBM disease is a fulminant autoimmune condition causing crescentic glomerulonephritis with pathognomonic linear IgG deposition, often presenting with concurrent pulmonary hemorrhage, requiring emergency plasmapheresis and aggressive immunosuppression.

explanation.intuition: Imagine antibodies as 'missiles' that specifically target the 'mortar' (type IV collagen) holding the glomerular and alveolar 'bricks' together. The resulting damage is like a building's foundation crumbling - the kidney's filtering units and lungs' air-blood barrier both fail rapidly.
explanation.key_insight: The LINEAR pattern on immunofluorescence is PATHOGNOMONIC - this smooth, ribbon-like IgG staining along the entire GBM is unique to anti-GBM disease and instantly distinguishes it from granular patterns seen in immune complex diseases. Time is kidney - early treatment before creatinine rises significantly is crucial.
explanation.technical_details: The Goodpasture antigen is the non-collagenous domain 1 (NC1) of the alpha-3(IV) chain. This epitope is normally hidden within the collagen structure ('cryptic') but becomes exposed through environmental insults (infection, smoking, hydrocarbons). Antibody binding activates complement and recruits neutrophils, causing focal necrotizing GN with crescent formation.

definitions_glossary.anti_GBM_disease: Autoimmune disease with antibodies against glomerular basement membrane causing RPGN
definitions_glossary.Goodpasture_syndrome: Anti-GBM disease with concurrent pulmonary hemorrhage
definitions_glossary.Goodpasture_antigen: NC1 domain of alpha-3 chain of type IV collagen
definitions_glossary.linear_IF_pattern: Smooth ribbon-like immunofluorescence along GBM; pathognomonic for anti-GBM
definitions_glossary.crescentic_GN: Glomerulonephritis with cellular/fibrous crescents from Bowman's capsule proliferation
definitions_glossary.RPGN: Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis with renal failure over days to weeks
definitions_glossary.DAH: Diffuse alveolar hemorrhage; life-threatening pulmonary bleeding
definitions_glossary.plasmapheresis: Procedure removing plasma (and antibodies) and replacing with albumin/FFP
definitions_glossary.cryptic_epitope: Antigenic site normally hidden in protein structure
definitions_glossary.Alport_syndrome: Inherited collagen IV disorder; anti-GBM can develop post-transplant

pathophysiology.mechanism: IgG autoantibodies bind NC1 domain of alpha-3(IV) collagen, activating complement C3 and recruiting neutrophils, causing focal necrotizing injury and crescent formation

antigen_exposure.mechanism: Environmental insults damage alveolar BM, exposing normally cryptic Goodpasture antigen

tissue_targets.kidney: Glomerular basement membrane - alpha-3(IV) chain present in all glomeruli
tissue_targets.lung: Alveolar basement membrane - alpha-3(IV) chain present; requires additional insult (smoking) for hemorrhage

double_positive_disease.implications: May have better response to immunosuppression, higher relapse risk

clinical_presentation: RPGN: Oliguria, edema, hypertension, active sediment
Pulmonary hemorrhage: Hemoptysis, dyspnea, diffuse infiltrates
Constitutional symptoms: Fatigue, weight loss, arthralgias

renal_biopsy.immunofluorescence: Linear IgG along GBM (PATHOGNOMONIC); C3 often linear too

pulmonary_evaluation: DLCO: Increased (blood in alveoli absorbs CO)

acute_management.plasmapheresis: Daily or every other day for 2-3 weeks until antibody negative; removes circulating anti-GBM
acute_management.supportive: Dialysis if needed, PJP prophylaxis, transfusion for anemia

definition.@value: Autoimmune disease caused by antibodies against type IV collagen in glomerular and alveolar basement membranes, causing rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis and pulmonary hemorrhage

scopeNote.@value: Covers pathogenesis, diagnosis, and management of anti-GBM disease/Goodpasture syndrome

learning_objectives: Describe the pathogenesis of anti-GBM disease including target antigen
Recognize the pathognomonic linear IgG pattern on immunofluorescence
Differentiate anti-GBM disease from ANCA-associated vasculitis
Outline the treatment protocol including plasmapheresis timing
Predict renal prognosis based on presenting creatinine and biopsy findings
clinical_pearls: Linear IgG on IF = PATHOGNOMONIC for anti-GBM disease
Smoking activates lung involvement - cessation mandatory
Start plasmapheresis BEFORE biopsy results in classic presentation
20-30% are 'double positive' with ANCA - may have better prognosis
common_misconceptions: All anti-GBM patients have pulmonary hemorrhage - only 60-80%
Dialysis at presentation = no hope - some recover with aggressive treatment
Anti-GBM and ANCA are mutually exclusive - 20-30% are double positive

evidence.confidence_rationale: Based on KDIGO guidelines and comprehensive reviews
